Graphical abstract The Phillips catalyst, which accounts for a large fraction of the world’s linear polyethylene, is known for an induction period without appreciable ethylene consumption, followed by a period of rising activity, which together can last an hour or two. In this investigation, the effect of trace amounts of a ubiquitous contaminant, molecular oxygen, on the length of the induction period is determined. Experiments were conducted in a tubular flow reactor with a packed bed of 1 or 3 wt% Cr on SiO2. The protocol was to first treat Cr(VI)/SiO2 at a temperature of 600 °C in 50 % O2, then cool and adjust the residual O2 concentration at the reactor inlet to between about 50 to 500 ppm by an inert gas purge, with optional application of 1-hexene as reductant. Polymerization was conducted at a temperature of 100 °C and ethylene partial pressures of 10 to 18 kPa. The length of the induction period and the time to reach maximum activity correlated with the O2 concentration at the inlet. The observations were qualitatively confirmed by high-pressure (3.79 MPa) experiments with slurried catalyst, which also demonstrated that the effect of O2 can be transient, and the catalyst reaches its full polymerization activity. An adaptable model of competing reduction and reoxidation rates in the packed-bed reactor is presented that accurately predicts the length of the induction time based on O2 level and the amount of catalyst loaded into the reactor. . Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyethylene is the most common plastic [1], and a significant fraction of it, mostly high-density polyethylene, is produced by using the Phillips Cr/silica catalyst [2]. Notwithstanding the catalyst’s importance and its seemingly simple composition, the nature of the active sites is still a mystery [2]. One reason for this lack of knowledge is the process of active site generation. During the catalyst synthesis, chromium is bound to the silica support through high-temperature calcination, leading to chromate or dichromate with potentially a variety of structures [2–4]. These Cr(VI)-containing moieties on the surface of silica are converted to active sites upon exposure to ethylene in the polymerization plant. The generation of active sites is usually slow, with two distinguishable phases, which are shown in Fig. 1 a. First, there is an induction period of up to an hour until the first sites come on stream and ethylene consumption indicates the onset of polymerization. This delay is thought to be caused by the reduction of Cr(VI) and its subsequent or simultaneous alkylation to initiate the first polyethylene chain. Then, in a second step, there is an acceleration period as more sites gradually come on stream, until a steady maximum polymerization activity is reached [2]. The exact mechanism of the redox process and the resulting active complex of chromium are still controversial [2,5–11]. Moreover, the ethylene-initiated redox process and the subsequent insertion of ethylene to start a chain, are likely to be only partially successful during the commercial catalyst’s 1–2 h average lifetime, and not all chromium may become active. Reported values for percentage of active chromium range from 0.01 % to 98 % [2]. Better understanding of this redox process and the parameters affecting it is therefore needed. The presence of inhibitors, usually called “poisons”, can significantly affect the behavior of the Phillips catalyst (Fig. 1), including the length of the induction period, the maximum polymerization rate, and the polymer that it produces. To give a brief account of the literature, compounds as different as O2 [12], butylmercaptan [13], and diethylsulfide [13] have been reported to prolong the induction period if present. Investigations of poisoning during the fully developed polymerization rate are numerous, because in situ poisoning is a widely applied, general method [14,15] to determine the number or fraction of active sites. A defined amount of the poison is added, and the response of the polymerization activity is recorded. Poisons such as oxygen [12,16], water [16], carbon monoxide [12,17], carbon dioxide [2], methanol [12], acetone, acetaldehyde [16], acetylene [12], benzene, ammonia [2], triethylamine [12,18], 4-methylpyridine [9,19], trimethylmonochlorosilane [16], tetrachloromethane [2], n-butyl mercaptan [13], diethylsulfide [13], acetic acid [6], or argon [16] have been used to calculate an average number of active sites under the assumption that all sites are equally active. While most poisoning studies were undertaken with the purview of determining the number of active sites, it was also discovered that adding oxygen or carbon monoxide alters the polymer molecular weight at the cost of diminished catalyst activity, and this effect is exploited commercially [2]. The action of poisons can be distinguished into “temporary” (alternatively: “reversible”) effects, or “permanent” (“irreversible”) effects, as is illustrated in Fig. 1. What would be considered temporary is a prolongation of the induction period or an interim drop in activity, while the final maximum activity remains unchanged relative to a control experiment, indicating that ultimately the same number of sites come on stream (Fig. 1b). In contrast, irreversible poisoning implies that sites become permanently unavailable, and the catalyst never develops its full potential activity (Fig. 1c). In a batch process (which does not involve continuous catalyst addition) the injection of a small quantity of a poison causes an immediate loss in the polymerization rate. If the rate was rising at the time of poison introduction, and the quantity of poison is not too large, the polymerization rate often starts to rise again after an interim drop. This phenomenon may be misinterpreted as “reversible poisoning”, implying poisoned sites are regenerated. However, even after a certain percentage of sites have been irreversibly poisoned, the remaining un-reduced sites may continue to come on stream in the normal way, causing a continued rise in rate (Fig. 1c). The distinction between temporary and permanent requires a long enough observation span to determine the final activity. A particular molecule may act either way–temporary or permanent–, depending on its nature and on whether there is a mechanism for its depletion in the reactor or not. The timing of the poison addition can influence its effect. Unreduced and reduced chromium sites may display different susceptibilities to the poison, in which case the effect depends on when the poison is added − prior to ethylene admission, during the induction period, during the period of rising activity, or during steady state. Few investigations have addressed this issue specifically, and drawing information from different sources for comparison usually suffers from the change of additional parameters. For example, when carbon monoxide is added to the reactor prior to reduction of Cr(VI), it does not prolong the induction period, while it does reduce the maximum activity somewhat. In contrast, when carbon monoxide is adsorbed to pre-reduced chromium with valence Cr(II), prior to exposure to ethylene, it acts as a much more severe poison [12]. In another report, the application of hydrogen sulfide to determine the fraction of active sites was found to yield different results depending on whether the catalyst was in a Cr(II) or a Cr(III) state [20]. Thus, the state of the catalyst and the timing of the poison feeding − prior to, concomitant with, or post ethylene introduction − are parameters influencing the polymerization activity, in addition to the nature of the poison and its amount. Ubiquitous molecules such as oxygen, water, and carbon dioxide, and sometimes by-products of ethane cracking like acetylene or carbon monoxide, can severely diminish polymerization activity which can have important commercial consequences. Lower catalyst activity does not necessarily slow down the production rate, which is maintained by adding more catalyst. But it does increase production costs and lowers the quality of some polymer grades, by increasing color, long-chain branching, oxidative susceptibility [21] and metals content [22], the latter being restricted by law [23]. Thus, early papers already state the need for purified ethylene “freed of catalyst poisons such as water vapor, oxygen, and carbon monoxide” [24]. Molecular oxygen is on top of the list of molecules to be likely present as an uninvited species, for its obvious ubiquity and for the immediate precedence of the calcination step to the polymerization step in most laboratory settings [5–7,25,26] and almost always under commercial operations [2]. Only a few investigations have been published regarding the effect of oxygen, and they focus on the deliberate addition of O2. Oxygen has been used as a poison during the polymerization phase to determine the fraction of active sites [2], and it has been added early to the reactor and found to extend the induction period [12]. Oxygen seems to be unlike other poisons, having a very different, even opposite (i.e., lowering), effect on the polymer molecular weight [2]. While it has been claimed that oxygen acts irreversibly [27], there are reasons to suspect that, at least under some conditions, poisoning of Cr catalysts by oxygen may truly be “reversible” [2]. Because of the scarcity of prior reports and the general lack of measurements of the actual O2 concentrations that would indicate the base (background) level in the apparatus used, the effect of trace levels of O2 has not been quantitatively described. At the same time, contaminants such as O2 or other molecules may be the reason for some of the discrepancies in the literature if their presence goes unnoticed. Here, we quantitatively investigate the effect of O2 on the induction time of ethylene polymerization in a scenario where O2 is already present when ethylene is introduced. 1-Hexene, which was co-fed in prior experiments that targeted the effect of O2 [12], is used as a pre-reductant. The experiments are conducted in a packed bed reactor with gaseous ethylene in plug flow, which, while impractical for polymer production, does provide spatial resolution of active and inactive catalyst zones and new insights. Experiments in a slurry reactor under commercially relevant conditions complement the data. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Several batches each of two Cr(VI)/SiO2 catalysts distinguished by their chromium loading were prepared as follows. A commercial polymerization-grade silica gel was obtained from W.R. Grace Co. under the trade name Sylopol HA30W. It had a BET surface area of about 500 m2/g, a N2 sorption pore volume of 1.63 ml/g, an average particle size of 87 µm, and an average pore diameter of 13.0 nm. To make the catalysts, batches of 100–200 g of this silica were impregnated with 1 wt% Cr or 3 wt% Cr, by first dissolving the correct amount of CrO3 into 2.0 ml/g of deionized water. Then the solution was added to the silica and stirred by hand vigorously, producing the consistency of a damp sand. This mixture was then allowed to dry, with stirring, and with a final drying in an oven at 110 °C. Some experiments used a Cr/silica-titania catalyst, which is also widely employed commercially. A few percent of titania is added as a molecular weight regulator. It tends to increase overall activity as well, but the kinetic profile and other characteristics are identical to plain Cr/silica [2,28]. To initially calcine, or “activate” the catalyst, about 10 g was placed in a 1.75 in. (4.45 cm) quartz tube fitted with a sintered quartz disk at the bottom. While the catalyst was supported on the disk, air (dried through a bed of 13X molecular sieve) was blown up through the disk at the rate of about 1.6 to 1.8 standard cubic feet per hour (0.76 to 0.85 l/min). An electric furnace around the quartz tube was then turned on and the temperature was raised at the rate of 400 degrees centigrade per hour to the indicated temperature. At that temperature the silica was allowed to fluidize for three hours in the dry air. Then the quartz was removed from the furnace and the catalyst allowed to cool to room temperature. The gas stream was then changed to dry N2, which continued to fluidize the catalyst for another 30 min, to remove all traces of oxygen. Afterward the catalyst was collected and stored under dry nitrogen, where it was protected from the atmosphere until ready for testing. For the packed-bed reactor experiments, the catalyst was calcined at 400 °C or 650 °C in the fluidized bed as described above. Then, it was shipped in sealed flasks, transferred and reactivated as detailed below. The behavior of different batches of catalyst (distinguished by their original calcination temperature) in the packed-bed reactions was similar, and they are therefore not distinguished in the plots. For the high-pressure experiments with slurried catalyst, the calcination temperature was 871 °C, and the catalyst was never allowed to experience any exposure to the atmosphere. 2.2 Experiments in packed-bed flow reactor 2.2.1 Gases Nitrogen (N2) and oxygen (O2) were from Airgas and ultrahigh purity (99.999 %). As per specification, N2 may contain up to 1 ppm of O2, 1 ppm of H2O, and 100 ppm of argon. Nitrogen was passed through a ZPure™ Glass High Sensitivity Moisture trap & ZPure™ Glass oxygen purifier. Oxygen was passed through a ZPure™ Glass High Sensitivity Moisture trap. Ethylene (C2H4) from Matheson, specified as research purity (99.999 %), was used. Ethylene was passed through an OxiClearTM disposable purifier. Analytical grade 1-hexene from Fluka Chemical Corp. was used without further purification. 2.2.2 Gas manifold and analytical instruments A gas manifold consisting of 1/8 in. (3.18 mm) stainless-steel tubing and Swagelok® fittings with two possible flow patterns through the tubular packed bed reactor as outlined in Fig. 2 was used for the experiments. The complete manifold with all details is shown in Fig. S1. Four-way valves (Vici) at the top and bottom of the reactor allowed switching the flow pattern: While one stream passed through the reactor, the other stream passed through the bypass. The common segment of tubing between the upstream four-way valve and the reactor was about 1.5 m. This segment incorporated a Bourdon tube pressure gauge (Swagelok). One side of the manifold was used for the oxidative activation of the catalyst, whereas the other side was kept O2-free and used to deliver the ethylene feed for polymerization, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Either stream could be sent to a GC for analysis. Variation of the line temperature after the first four-way valve between room temperature and 200 °C did not affect the results in a detectable manner. Bronkhorst mass flow controllers were used; thus, the specified volumetric flow rates are referenced to a temperature of 0 °C and a pressure of 1013 hPa. The reactor effluent stream was continuously analyzed by a Pfeiffer Omnistar GSD 320 O2 MS with tungsten filaments. For quantitative analysis of the polymerization rate, a Varian Series 3800 GC with gas sampling valve and flame ionization detection was employed. A fused silica PLOT column (60 m x 0.32 mm) or a PORA PLOT Q column (25 m × 0.32 mm) was used for the separation. Injections were performed at split ratios between 6 and 20 depending on the partial pressure of ethylene and the type of column used. 2.2.3 Catalyst transfer and reactor Cr (VI)/SiO2 was transferred from its storage flask to a container for weighing and then to a tubular reactor using a glove bag under N2 atmosphere to avoid contact of the catalyst with ambient air. The reactor tube was made of quartz, with an O.D. of 3/8″ (O.D. of 9.5 mm, I.D. of 7 mm) and a length between 16.5″ and 17.0″ (between 42 cm and 43 cm). Quartz wool was used to support the catalyst bed. In a typical experiment, between 300 to 650 mg of catalyst was loaded into the reactor. A mass of 520 mg with 1 wt% loading corresponds to 100 µmol of chromium. The reactor was sealed with Parafilm for a few minutes until it was connected to the gas manifold via Swagelok fittings and Viton O-rings, and N2 via the “Activation Gas” line was streamed immediately. The reactor was used in downflow mode. The tube was placed into a tubular furnace 12.5“ (32 cm) in length such that the catalyst bed (length ∼2 to 5 cm depending on the mass used) was in the isothermal zone. 2.2.4 Pretreatment of the catalyst and purge The catalyst was pretreated by heating to a temperature of 600 °C at a rate of 10 K/min in a 50 ml/min flow of 50 vol% O2 and 50 vol% N2 and holding at 600 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the catalyst was cooled to a reaction temperature of 100 °C at a rate of 10 K/min, whereby the gas stream was switched to 50 ml/min N2 at 300 °C. The flow rate of 50 ml/min corresponds to a linear (superficial) velocity of 2.2 cm/s. The effluent stream composition, including H2O, CO2, and O2 levels, was monitored during the entire activation by using MS. Fig. 3 shows a typical protocol, which is characterized by activation, purge period, and polymerization. The purge period is considered to be the isothermal period at a temperature of 100 °C after the activation has ended, where activation includes cooling in inert gas once the temperature has fallen below 300 °C. To reduce the likelihood that possible residual traces of O2 (from wall adsorption, dead volume) were present in the system during polymerization, tubing and reactor were purged after the use of O2. The length of this purge period after the activation was varied between a few minutes to 4 h. In some experiments, N2 was replaced by argon (as specified in figure captions). 2.2.5 Addition of external reductants In some experiments, 1-hexene was introduced into the inert gas stream during the purge period. A syringe was used to inject pulses of 1-hexene with a liquid volume of 2 µl, corresponding to about 16 µmol, through a septum upstream of the catalyst bed (Fig. 2). The pulses vaporized in the gas stream. 2.2.6 Polymerization conditions Following activation, purge, and optional reductant application, polymerizations were conducted at a temperature of 100 °C. Ethylene was diluted in N2 or Ar to the desired partial pressure between 10 and 20 kPa while maintaining a total gas flow rate of 50 ml/min. Ethylene partial pressures were set by adjusting ethylene flow rates using mass flow controllers and manufacturer-specified gas type-dependent correction factors for ethylene relative to the design gas for which the mass flow controller was originally calibrated. The flow controllers are precise, and flow rates are reproducible, but the correction factors are known to not be perfectly accurate. Hence, small systematic deviations of the actual from the nominal value are possible. The polymerization stage of the experiment (#3 in Fig. 3) was initiated by admitting ethylene to the reactor, which was accomplished by switching the two four-way valves indicated in Fig. 2. “Time on stream” in the graphs starts at this switch. 2.2.7 Analysis of O2 concentrations in gas streams To estimate the level of O2 in the reactor outlet stream, calibrations were developed for the mass spectrometer that was connected online for reactor effluent analysis. For the oxygen calibration, O2 and N2 or O2 and Ar were mixed in various compositions between 1 and 10 vol% O2 with the help of mass flow controllers. Because of some fluctuations in MS sensitivity over time, nitrogen or argon at 100 % was used as a standard to which to refer the O2 signal, and these ratio-based calibrations were generally found to be very stable over months, unless the mass spectrometer was tuned. The measurements were made with a Faraday cup to ensure linearity, at the expense of higher sensitivity that could be achieved with the secondary electron multiplier. The detection limit is less than 40 ppm as per the manufacturer, and the noise level was found to be around 25 ppm O2. The calibration showed a linear dependency of the O2 signal on concentration, as shown in Fig. S2. The factors obtained from the slopes were also used to determine concentrations lower than the calibration range, by interpolating the linear fit to an intercept of (0,0). Not forcing the intercept to be (0,0) changed the slopes by 8 % or less, validating this approach. 2.2.8 Quantitative analysis of ethylene feed and reactor effluent stream by GC The ethylene concentration at the outlet of the reactor was obtained with the help of the GC. Since ethylene was fed from a different part of the manifold than the gas mixture for activation and purge (Fig. 1), the composition of the feed could be analyzed by sending the bypass stream to the GC. This mode of operation allowed setting up a stable feed stream prior to admitting it to the reactor. Time on stream in figure captions starts with admission of ethylene. Gas chromatography was used to determine ethylene conversion. The response factor was calculated for each experiment by taking several bypass measurements (in the absence of catalyst) with 10 % ethylene to account for day-to-day variations. 2.3 High-pressure experiments in semi-batch reactor with slurried catalyst 2.3.1 Gases Ethylene was obtained from Union Carbide as polymerization grade and then it was further purified by passage through large beds of 13X molecular sieve and activated charcoal. Isobutane was obtained from Phillips Petroleum, and then further purified by passage through a 13X molecular sieve bed. Both oxygen and carbon monoxide were purified prior to use by passage through a 13X molecular sieve bed. 2.3.2 Polymerizations Polymerization tests were conducted in a 2.2 L stainless steel reactor equipped with a marine stirrer running at 400 rpm. The reactor was surrounded by a steel jacket circulating water, the temperature of which was controlled by use of steam and water heat exchangers. These were connected in an electronic feed-back loop so that the reactor temperature could be maintained at +/- 0.5 °C during the reaction. In each run, the empty reactor was first allowed to purge with dry nitrogen at about 100 °C for 30 min. Then a small quantity, typically 0.05 to 0.10 g, of the calcined chromium catalyst was charged under nitrogen to the dry reactor. The reactor valve was then closed and the nitrogen flow was stopped. Then 1.2 L of isobutane liquid was charged and the reactor heated up to the specified temperature, usually 105 °C or 110 °C. Finally, ethylene was added to the reactor to equal a fixed pressure, normally 550 psig (3.8 MPa), which was maintained during the experiment. The entire charging and start-up procedure took about 5 min. The stirring was allowed to continue for the specified time, usually 1 to 2 h, and the instantaneous polymerization rate was noted by recording the flow of ethylene into the reactor to maintain the set pressure. After the allotted time, the ethylene flow was stopped and the reactor slowly depressurized and opened to recover a granular polymer powder. In all cases the reactor was clean with no indication of any wall scale, coating or other forms of fouling. The polymer powder was then removed and weighed. Final average activity was specified as grams of polymer produced per gram of solid catalyst charged per hour of run-time. 2.3.3 Poisoning experiments with O2 Oxygen was added in the desired amount by prior-blending of partial pressures for the poison and ethylene into a 1 L stainless steel cylinder, that was then connected to the reactor before it was started up. Then, at the desired time, either before the start of the run or during the run, when ethylene was being consumed and pulled into the reactor at a high flow, valves were switched so that the ethylene would flow through the cylinder containing poison. 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of O2 content in packed-bed reactor system 3.1.1 Empty reactor purge and switch of streams The O2 content in the reactor effluent was monitored continuously by MS. After changing the activation gas mixture with 50 % O2 to pure N2, the O2 concentration dropped with time, while remaining above the detection limit even if the system was purged with N2 for hours. To achieve a feed stream that is as clean as possible for the polymerization experiment, the ethylene feed part of the manifold was kept O2-free. Notwithstanding these measures, traces of O2 were present. The O2 concentrations were exceeding the levels present in the ethylene tank (specified as 1 ppm or less) and therefore also exceeding typical specifications for the feed in ethylene polymerization plants (also 1 ppm or less [27]). The contamination thus did not stem from the source (the tank) but was acquired en route from the tank to the reactor. To assess the O2 concentration that the catalysts experience at the time when the ethylene feed is introduced, an experiment with an empty reactor was conducted, with the reactor heated to 100 °C. Fig. 4 shows the decline in oxygen concentration during the N2 purge and the significant step down in concentration upon the switch from the manifold section used for activation to the manifold section with the feed stream. Both before and after the switch, the concentration was found to decrease according to a first-order exponential function, as given in Eq. (1). (1) c O 2 t = c O 2 t o ∗ e - k t - t 0 + y 0 Where c is the concentration of oxygen, t is time and k is a first-order rate constant. Further, y0 is a baseline offset, t0 is the beginning of the time interval selected for fitting, and c(t0) the corresponding concentration. Before the gas switch (from 175 to 210 min in Fig. 4), the rate constant describes the decrease in O2 concentration during the purge period with N2. The rate constant k was determined for various purge times and O2 levels and found to be around 0.07–0.08 min−1 for c O2(t0) of 100 to 5000 ppm. The bulk of the gas in the reactor and lines is exchanged quickly, at a flow rate of 50 ml/min relative to a reactor volume of 16.5 ml. Residual O2 is thus from small dead volumes (e.g., the pressure gauge) and wall desorption. After the switch (past 210 min in Fig. 4), a value of the rate constant of 0.06 min−1 was found, that is, on the same order of magnitude but slightly lower. 3.1.2 Molecular oxygen (O2) level during purge of catalyst bed The effect of the purge period on the O2 concentration at the reactor exit in the presence of a packed bed of catalyst is shown in Fig. 5 . The O2 concentrations from a large number of experiments just prior to admission of ethylene fall on one curve. The combined data reproduce the decline observed in the corresponding individual experiments, with little scatter. The purge time is the dominant factor, and there was no pronounced effect of parameters such as bed length or catalyst composition. Regarding the possible influence of the catalyst on oxygen retention in the reactor, additional considerations and measurements were made. The tapped density of the catalyst is 0.28 g/ml, implying that a 1 g bed would have a void volume of 3.1 ml. All packed beds were less than 1000 mg. The meso- and micropore volumes of the silica that contribute to this void volume and would be more difficult to exchange, are 1.6 ml/g and 0.04 mL/g or less. Another possibility for an oxygen reservoir in the reactor is adsorption of O2 on the catalyst. According to the literature, silica is able to adsorb small amounts of O2, on the order of 4.2 µmol per 500 mg SiO2 at a temperature of 100 °C and 1 atm pressure [29]. A thermogravimetry experiment with the same activation and purge protocol (Fig. S3) however showed that there is no evidence of slow desorption of O2 or release from pores of the catalyst during the purge period. Finally, weak adsorption of oxygen on chromium would be a possibility to retain O2 in the packed bed [30], whereas release of O2 through thermal decomposition is usually observed only at higher temperatures [31]. To place the size of this potential reservoir in context, a mass of 520 mg of 1 % Cr/SiO2 in the reactor corresponds to an amount of 100 µmol of chromium, while a concentration of 500 ppm of O2 at a flow rate of 50 ml/min corresponds to an O2 influx of 1.1 µmol/min. However, the fact that different catalysts (1 or 3 wt% chromium) and variation of the reactor loading (by more than a factor 2) do not affect the O2 concentration in the effluent visibly implies that species trapped in the bed are not a major O2 source in these experiments. The main O2 source is thus the incoming gas stream. 3.1.3 Finding a measure of the O2 level during polymerization To investigate the influence of O2 on the polymerization profile, the O2 level in the reactor during initiation and catalysis would be of interest. However, as soon as ethylene was fed to the reactor packed with catalyst, the O2 level in the effluent was so low that it was indeterminable, that is, somewhere below the detection limit of the MS of an estimated 40 ppm. Therefore, an alternative, indirect measure of the O2 content in the reactor needed to be identified. The O2 concentration 5 min prior to switching the inlet stream to the ethylene feed (illustrated in Fig. S4) was chosen as an alternative indicator of the O2 level in the reactor. The underlying assumption is that the concentration after the switch relates to the concentration before the switch by a proportionality factor that is largely independent of concentration. The behavior of O2 in the inlet stream over time is predictable through Eq. (1). 3.2 Induction period and polymerization activity in packed-bed reactor 3.2.1 Reaction profile The polymerization activity was monitored by GC for quantitative analysis (Fig. 6 a) and by MS for time resolution (Fig. 6b). By inspecting both types of data sets for multiple experiments, four phases could be identified: an induction time with no activity, a period of rising activity, a period of declining activity, and a subsequent period of steady or slowly increasing activity. The first two phases are expected. Based on the literature [32], the decline in rate may be the result of mass transfer limitations through the growing polymer particles. The late rise in activity may be the result of increasing pressure in the packed bed. Namely, when polymer formation was significant, the pressure upstream of the packed bed rose, and the experiment had to be terminated, preventing collection of data at longer reaction times. Since ethylene conversions reached up to 80 % at the maximum, and the polymerization is known to be first order in ethylene [2], mass-based rates are non-differential and merely serve the purpose of accounting for different bed lengths in comparisons. The focus is on the induction time, which is not affected by reactor clogging or high conversions. Fig. 6b illustrates how the exact length of the induction period (from “Ethylene admitted” to “Onset”) and the time until maximum ethylene conversion (from “Ethylene admitted” to “Maximum”) were obtained from mass spectrometry. While the MS data have a drift and artifacts, onset and maximum can be clearly identified. 3.2.2 Effect of purge period and O2 concentration on time to onset and polymerization rate The parameter of interest for its influence on the polymerization performance is the purge period, because it determines the O2 content in the system. Catalyst mass, chromium content of catalyst, and ethylene partial pressures were varied to a small extent in contrast to the purge time, which was varied significantly. The length of the purge period in inert gas, defined as the isothermal period at 100 °C starting after activation in 50 % O2 in N2 and subsequent cooling, and ending with the admission of ethylene for the polymerization test, affected the reaction profile in a systematic manner. The data in Fig. 7 indicate that the time until maximum becomes shorter with increasing purge time, meriting further investigation. In contrast, an influence of the purge period on the observed rate is not obvious. A compilation of many data points for the time to onset as determined from MS data, is shown in Fig. 8 a. The graph demonstrates that the time to onset decreases with increasing length of the purge period, first rapidly and then more slowly. The purge period needed to minimize the onset time is about 1 h for the 1 wt% catalyst and about 30 min for the 3 wt% catalyst. Fig. 4 and Fig. 8 together suggest a correlation between onset time and O2 content before the switch. In the next data processing step, the length of the purge period was replaced with the instantaneous O2 concentration (5 min before the switch to the polymerization feed). By combining the information, Fig. 8b was generated, which shows the times to onset as a function of O2 concentration for various batches of 1 wt% catalyst. This plot demonstrates a relationship between O2 concentration and time to onset. The existence of a correlation suggests that the O2 concentration detected before the switch to ethylene is a good predictor of subsequent events. There is increasing scatter in the plot at higher O2 concentrations. It is noticeable that higher ethylene partial pressures (i.e., 15–20 kPa instead of 10 kPa) consistently result in lower onset times. The total flow rate during the polymerization phase was also varied, to probe for the role of gas exchange in the reactor. The highlighted data points in Fig. 8b do not indicate any pronounced effect of the flow rate; rather, they follow the trend and fall within the scatter. One explanation is the potential for opposing effects, since with a higher purge rate, the inlet concentration may drop faster while more O2 would be introduced, at least initially. Another explanation is the time scale of the gas exchange: at a reactor volume of 16.5 ml and a standard flow rate of 50 ml/min, the bulk gas is exchanged within ≈20 s, which is negligible relative to the time scales of the observed effects. Consequently, a model would have to account for different partial pressures, while additional parameters not highlighted in Fig. 8 must play a role in explaining the spread among data points obtained at the same partial pressure. A similar analysis can be made using time to maximum rather than the time to onset, but the correlation is weaker (Fig. S5). In contrast, an effect of the purge time on the average polymerization activity (determined over a time period of 120 min or until the maximum conversion, as illustrated in Fig. S6) could not be extracted, as is evident from Fig. S7a. A plot of the average polymerization rate versus O2 concentration (Fig. S7b) shows as much variation at any of the low concentrations as across all concentrations. 3.3 Zone formation in the packed bed and use of reductant 1-hexene 3.3.1 Zone formation Additional information was gathered from post-polymerization analysis of the reactor bed. The Phillips catalyst typically exhibits a bright orange color at about 1 wt% chromium, and a deeper orange to reddish color with increasing chromium loading. After executing the protocol, consisting of activation, purge, and polymerization, the catalyst bed was found to no longer exhibit the original bright light orange color. Photos taken after removal of the reactor from the oven shortly after disconnecting the gas flow are shown in Fig. 9 a. A dull orange zone at the top and a gray zone at the bottom were observed, both different in color from fresh catalyst. The material in the gray zone tended to be sticky, suggesting that polymerization had occurred in this zone. The presence of polymer was confirmed by taking a sample from this section and recording an IR scan as shown in Fig. 9b. The DRIFT spectrum shows bands at 2935 cm−1 and 2858 cm−1 corresponding to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of the CH2 group of the polymer chain [33] and with distortions typical of DRIFT spectra of PE [34]. Additional bands in the NIR region match reported spectra very well, and bands at 4322 cm−1 and 4251 cm−1 can be assigned to the combination modes of polyethylene vibrations [35]. Thus, polymerization occurred in the gray zone of the packed bed. The length of the gray zone varied; the zone always included the bottom (downstream) end of the bed and could amount to as much as ≈95 % of the bed. An analysis of the length of the gray zone further confirmed it as the polymerization zone. As Fig. 10 a demonstrates, the length correlates with the total ethylene consumption (determined from the data shown in Fig. S8). The upstream portion changed color from bright orange to a duller orange but did not produce polyethylene. To distinguish whether the length of the polymerization zone is the result of polymerization commencing at the downstream end of the bed or the result of an irreversibly O2-poisoned zone extending from the upstream end of the bed, the length of the top zone was plotted versus the cumulative amount of oxygen introduced over the time on stream, assuming the concentration after the switch would drop as suggested by Fig. 4 and Eq. (1). This plot does not reveal any correlation (Fig. 10b), implying that the length of the top zone does not directly result from introduced O2. Variations of these plots using the ethylene consumption divided by the time on stream and the O2 concentration before the switch (Fig. S9) gave a similar result. 3.3.2 Use of reductant 1-hexene Pre-reduction of Cr(VI) with CO is sometimes used in commercial practice, and many other reductants have been tested in the literature, among them hydrocarbons. In the packed-bed experiments, one compound was tested as pre-reductant, 1-hexene, which is commonly co-polymerized with ethylene and can undergo a redox reaction with Cr(VI) when applied to the calcined catalyst [6,25,36]. 1-Hexene was applied in the form of pulses during the purge period with inert gas. A single pulse of 2 µl liquid corresponds to 16 µmol 1-hexene, that is, the pulses were on the order of magnitude of the amount of chromium in the reactor. 1-Hexene is very volatile and would not be expected to adsorb on silica at a temperature of 100 °C, and, consistent with its properties and the applied amounts, it was detected in the effluent by MS. The first pulse was partially consumed, as can be seen in Fig. 11 a, whereas a larger fraction of subsequent pulses passed through the bed. The O2 level experienced a sharp drop below the detection limit, already as a result of the first pulse. Photos of a catalyst bed exposed to 1-hexene pulses but not to ethylene show a greenish color throughout (Fig. 11b), implying that 1-hexene has reached and reacted with the entire bed. When ethylene was introduced after pre-reduction with 1-hexene, polymerization was immediate, that is, there was no induction time (Fig. 12 a). Moreover, there was also no period of rising activity; rather, the polymerization rate was at the maximum level from the outset. At the end of the reaction, the bed exhibited the gray color typical of the polymerization zone except for two thin layers of different color at the very top (Fig. 12b). 3.4 Corroboration of O2 effects in high-pressure experiments and their reversibility 3.4.1 Effect of O2 on induction period under high-pressure ethylene To ensure that the effects observed in the packed-bed reactor are transferable to commercially relevant conditions, similar experiments were conducted under high pressure conditions, with an ethylene partial pressure of 3.79 MPa. Fig. 13 shows the kinetic profiles of three experiments, using Cr(VI)/silica-titania. The first curve represents the polymerization behavior of an unperturbed fresh catalyst, which in this case is the control run. Then, in the next two runs oxygen was injected into the reactor prior to contact with ethylene. The induction time increased significantly with the quantity of oxygen added, similar to what is seen in Fig. 7, therefore corroborating the observations in the packed-bed reactor. 3.4.2 Test for reversibility of O2 poisoning The absence of a visibly O2-poisoned top zone could be taken as an indication for a temporary effect of O2, but further evidence is desirable, especially since the literature is divided on this issue. One report [12] hypothesized that O2 re-oxidizes active chromium species, which are then reduced again by ethylene. This sequence would make oxygen a “temporary poison”, implying that any decrease in reactivity should be largely reversible. In contrast, other sources claim that the effect of O2 is irreversible [27]. The illustrations of possible responses to poisons in Fig. 1 emphasize the necessity to observe the fully developed polymerization rate to distinguish between temporary and permanent poisoning effects. However, the packed-bed reactor setup compromises an accurate measurement of the maximum rate. Revisiting Fig. 13, it is evident that the period of rising activity is delayed when oxygen is added, and accordingly, the final rate is reached at a later time. To assess whether the final rate is negatively impacted, the uncertainty in this value was determined from a number of control runs and is indicated in Fig. 13 through a band representing the average deviation around the control run. Both runs with O2 added fall within this range, indicating that there is no significant permanent effect of O2 addition at the start of the run. An additional experiment with addition of O2 during the period of rising activity (Fig. S10) shows that the activity drops after O2 is introduced but then rises to about the same level as seen for an unperturbed catalyst. Fig. 13, Fig. S10 and, indirectly, Fig. S7, taken together, provide strong evidence of near-complete reversibility of the effect of O2. A possible explanation is that Cr(VI) sites are reduced by ethylene, then immediately re-oxidized by the oxygen injection, followed by re-reduction over time by ethylene. During the period of the long induction, oxygen is being consumed, and polymerization does not commence until all the oxygen has been removed. 4 Discussion 4.1 Model for induction time Prior reports have demonstrated a principal effect of O2 on the induction time [2,12], and also showed that higher amounts of O2 resulted in longer times. The observations in Fig. 8b are consistent with prior work while giving the first picture of a mathematical relationship. It is evident from the data in Fig. 8b that the onset time depends on the residual O2 concentration in the system. The scatter suggests that additional parameters play a role, one of them is the ethylene partial pressure. A model was developed to calculate the onset time. The model is based on the following hypothesis: Initially, the bed contains oxidized chromium Cr(VI), as a result of the in situ treatment in 50 % O2. Once ethylene is admitted, chromium sites are being reduced. Residual O2 from the gas delivery system continues to enter the reactor and reoxidizes chromium. The balance between the rate of reduction and the rate of reoxidation determines whether the entire bed remains in an oxidized and inactive state, or net reduction of chromium occurs, leading to active sites and polymerization. Since the inlet O2 concentration declines over time, while the ethylene influx is constant, reduction eventually prevails, and polymerization commences. It is well known that reduced chromium can serve to create an O2 trap [37]; in fact, chromium oxide can serve as an ingredient of commercial cartridges for purification of gases from O2. The oxygen concentration therefore decreases over the length of the bed, as in a fixed-bed adsorption [38], which explains the preferred formation of polymer towards the downstream end of the bed. The localization of oxidized and reduced chromium in specific zones is unique to the fixed bed reactor. While spatial gradients in catalyst and gas composition determine the polymerization zone, they may not be needed to predict the induction time in a reactor, that is, a simple model without considering spatial gradients, may suffice. Such a model would also be applicable to commonly employed semi-batch polymerization reactors. The reduction and oxidation reactions can only be formulated in a generalized way (Reaction Eq. (1) and Reaction Eq. (2), since the exact products and valence of the reduced chromium are not known. Hence, instead of numeric values, the reaction equations contain the absolute values of the unknown stoichiometric numbers νred and νox , which are both negative. (2) The production rate of reduced chromium is given by Eq. (2). (2) R C r r e d = r red + r ox Where rred and rox are the net reaction rates of Reaction (1) and Reaction (2), respectively. The induction time can be obtained by equating reduction and oxidation rates as per Eq. (3). (3) r red = r ox The rate of reduction rred in the entire reactor can be expressed by Eq. (4): (4) r red = k red p Et α ∫ 0 m c Cr ( V I ) d m Here r red is the rate in mol min−1, kred is the rate constant for reduction in kPa-α min−1, pEt is the ethylene partial pressure in kPa, α is the order in ethylene, and cCr(VI) is the concentration of chromium (VI) in mol g−1 and m is the mass of catalyst in the reaction in g. The concentration of ethylene is assumed to be constant throughout the reactor during the induction period, which is justified by both experiment and theory. Experimentally, the catalyst beds do not produce a significant pressure drop prior to polymerization, and no ethylene consumption is detected during the induction time. It is useful to assess what the theoretical ethylene conversion could be. There is a large excess of ethylene over oxygen, at a C2H4 concentration of ≥ 100,000 ppm and O2 concentration of < 1000 ppm. The ethylene influx is about 200 µmol min−1, the O2 influx is up to 1.6 µmol min−1, while the amount of chromium in the reactor is between 52 and 160 µmol in the analyzed data set. Therefore, ethylene consumption will be minute as long as reduction and reoxidation counteract each other and there is no net reduction of chromium. Without axial ethylene gradient, reduction occurs over the entire length of the bed at a similar rate. It is assumed that the reduction rate is proportional to the concentration of chromium (VI) sites. The initial chromium (VI) concentration can be calculated from the catalyst mass loaded into the reactor and the catalyst’s chromium content. The concentration of chromium was 1 wt% in the entire analyzed data set, and, therefore, an effect of site density on the kinetics could not be extracted. The rate of oxidation in the entire reactor is equal to the amount of consumed O2 per time and can be expressed by Eq. (5): (5) r ox = 1 ν ox ( F O 2 , i n - F O 2 , o u t ) Where F O 2 , i n is the flow of O2 into the reactor and F O 2 , o u t is the flow at the exit of the reaction, both in mol min−1. The O2 concentration at the inlet after the switch is assumed to be describable by a fixed factor 1/x of the measured value before the switch. The drop of the O2 concentration with time follows an exponential function as found in Fig. 4. These considerations lead to Eq. (6) for the influx of O2. (6) F O 2 , i n = 1 x F c O 2 , b e f o r e e - k drop t Where c02 ,before is the O2 concentration in mol ml−1 before the switch, x is a number that determines the step down in O2 concentration at the switch, kdrop in min−1 is the rate constant for the first order decline in oxygen concentration, and F is the total flow rate in ml min−1. Substituting Eq. (4) and the combination of Eq. (5) and Eq. (6) into Eq. (3) and lumping the switch factor x and the stoichiometric number νox into k’red as per Eq. (7) produces Eq. (8). (7) k red ' = x ν ox k red (8) F c O 2 , b e f o r e e - k drop t - x F O 2 , o u t = k ' red p Et α n C r ( V I ) Where nCr(VI) is the amount substance of chromium in the reactor. Formation of reduced chromium will occur when the O2 concentration at the outlet is equal to 0 ppm, and the influx of O2 corresponds to the reduction rate. Therefore, the onset time tonset can be obtained via Eq. (9): (9) t onset = - 1 k drop l n k ' red p Et α n C r ( V I ) F c O 2 , b e f o r e Eq. (9) will give • tonset = 0 if the amount of chromium in the reactor happens to be such that the rate of reduction suffices to compensate for the oxygen influx at the time of the switch; • a positive value for tonset if the O2 concentration needs to decline; • a negative value for tonset if there is more catalyst than needed for net reduction to occur immediately towards the downstream end of the bed. The Solver module in Excel was used to fit the parameters in Eq. (9) by minimizing the sum of the squared differences between measured and calculated onset times. Since “negative” times correspond to the lack of an induction period in the experiment, the MAX function in Excel was used to replace negative values by zero, which allowed for comparison with the experimentally observed values. Fits were conducted with and without constraining the order α. The results of the fits are given in Table 1 . A first fit with an unconstrained reaction order in ethylene gave a value of 1.19 for α. When α was constrained to 1 in a second attempt, the residual increased marginally. The difference suggests that the order in ethylene is possibly larger than 1 but could not be extracted given the few experiments with different ethylene partial pressures. The value obtained for kdrop is 0.03 min−1 and, therefore, on the same order of magnitude as was observed with the empty reactor, suggesting it is a reasonable value. While the rate constant for reduction incorporates the factor x and the stoichiometric factor νox , neither of these factors assumes very larges values – x is around 2 according to Fig. 4, and νox is likely to be between 1 and 2 depending on whether Cr(IV), Cr(II) or an intermediate oxidation state is formed. Therefore, the true rate constant for reduction kred is probably on the same order of magnitude as k’red . A comparison between measured and predicted onset times is shown in Fig. 14 for α = 1. The points scatter around the parity line, as should be in the absence of any systematic deviations, and the trendline is close to parity. The experiments with higher ethylene partial pressures align reasonably, demonstrating that the behavior at small partial pressure variations is captured. Two measurements performed at different flow rates of 30 ml min−1 and 70 ml min−1 instead of the default 50 ml min−1 were not used for the regression (or the trendline), as the O2 drop rate would be expected to increase or decrease at higher or lower flow rate. Consistent with this notion, the onset time for the higher flow rate is significantly overestimated while the onset time for the lower flow rate is slightly underestimated. As can be seen from Fig. 14, the model accurately predicts the onset time, with the determining factor being the residual O2 concentration and its evolution over time. At infinitely low O2 concentration, the model predicts that there is no induction period. Consequently. no other chemistry needs to be inferred to explain the length of the induction period until onset of polymerization. While the oxygen level and drop rate may be unique to the employed apparatus, the model is transferable. For any reactor configuration, the release of oxygen from a reservoir (e.g., a dead volume) or influx of oxygen (e.g., from a feed flow) have to be identified, the equations adapted, and then a similar prediction could be made. The rate of reduction depends on the ethylene partial pressure and on the amount of chromium present in the reactor. Consequently, catalysts with higher chromium content (3 vs 1 wt%) were less susceptible to the O2 concentration and generally characterized by a short induction period. 4.2 Period of rising activity Past the onset time, that is, once reduction prevails, the change in the amount of Cr(VI) can be expressed by Eq. (10), which includes the rate of reduction and the rate of oxidation. Solving allows calculating the amount of Cr(VI) in the reactor as a function of time via Eq. (11). (11) n Cr ( V I ) = e - k red ′ p Et α t F O 2 , o n s e t k ′ red p Et α - k drop e ( k ′ red p Et α - k drop ) t + C Where C is given by Eq. (12), assuming that at onset, the amount of Cr(VI) is equal to the total amount of chromium. (12) C = n Cr , t o t a l - F O 2 , o n s e t k ′ red p Et α - k drop The amount of reduced chromium as a function of time is then obtained via Eq. (13). (13) n Cr , r e d = n Cr , t o t a l - n Cr ( V I ) By using this model, the net amount of reduced chromium at the point when the maximum polymerization rate is reached can be projected and was found to be up to 14 % of the total chromium in the reactor for 1 % Cr samples under the conditions tested. Fig. 15 shows that as the amount of reduced chromium increases in the reactor over time, the conversion of ethylene as measured by GC increases. Since the time resolution of the GC data is limited, the MS signal representative of ethylene (m/z = 27) is also shown and found to decrease mirroring the trend in reduced chromium. Without having to infer other chemical processes, the rising polymerization rate is thus explainable by more and more sites becoming reduced and, presumably, active. While reduction and site activation by alkylation have been considered as separate events for many years, more recent literature suggests they may not be [36]. This latest view is consistent with the observations here that show the reduction and reoxidation chemistry to control both the length of the induction period and the rise in activity. Given the limitations of polymerization in the packed bed reactor, where filling of the voids with polymer leads to rising pressure drop and self-limitation, time-dependent behavior at longer times on stream is not interpreted here. When the amount of ethylene consumed was assessed, an effect of the oxygen concentration or oxygen exposure on the steady state polymerization rate was not discernable (Fig. S7). This finding is consistent with the notion of O2 as a temporary poison (competitive adsorption) or a reversible poison (re-oxidation of already reduced sites followed by re-reduction of sites). The lack of an effect of O2 on the polymerization rate is documented in prior reports [12]. 4.3 Effect of 1-hexene as a reductant This interpretation of the period of rising activity as a period of declining O2 concentration and simultaneously increasing number of reduced, active sites is further supported by the observation after pre-reduction with 1-hexene. Already a single pulse of 1-hexene led to a drop of the O2 level below the detection limit. The drop of the O2 concentration after 1-hexene pulses can be explained with the formation of reduced sites that act as an O2 trap. The partial consumption of the first pulse and the green color of the entire bed after hexene pulses totaling a 1:1 or higher ratio of 1-hexene:Cr is evidence of wide-spread reduction. The influx of O2 is estimated to be less than 1 µmol min−1 at the beginning of the injections and about one order of magnitude less 100 min later when ethylene is introduced, while the bed length corresponded 60 to 70 µmol chromium. It is thus conceivable that all incoming O2 is trapped by reduced sites in the top zone of the bed. After stoichiometric application of 1-hexene, there is no induction time and no period of rising activity, but rather the rate reaches maximum level instantly (Fig. 12). There are two possible scenarios for the active sites. Given trapping of all oxygen in the top zone of the bed, Cr(VI) sites in the bottom zone that are reduced by the incoming ethylene will not be reoxidized for lack of O2 and become active. However, according to the model, reduction is a slow process at the applied ethylene partial pressures. Alternatively, the probably significant fraction of sites reduced by 1-hexene in the bed becomes active immediately upon admission of ethylene and catalyzes polymerization, largely unimpeded by any reoxidation reactions. This scenario is consistent with prior observation of generation of active sites from Cr(VI)/SiO2 by 1-hexene [6,36]. 4.4 Implications for the activation of Cr(VI)/SiO2 and use of reductants or activators In the literature, the length of the induction period is mostly discussed in context with the use of co-catalysts or reductants. The experimental protocol varies, sometimes the catalyst is activated again in situ in O2-containing atmosphere after transferring to the reactor or spectroscopic cell [5–7,25,26], whereas sometimes it is not [39,40]. It is however rarely obvious whether control experiments were performed in which the cell or reactor was purged or evacuated for a time span corresponding to the time span of “background” purge or evacuation while reductants or co-catalysts were administered. Further, the O2 concentration is not usually measured and may in fact be so low that it would escape detection by common analytical methods – what is assessed to be oxygen free may not be at 0 ppm. Similar arguments could be made for other ubiquitous poisons. The results here and in prior papers [12] show that ppm concentrations of O2 have an effect. It is therefore conceivable that trace O2 is often responsible for observed induction periods. The findings here provide new insights regarding the various effects that “reductants” can have. First, there may be no chemical effect of the reductant itself at all, and the protocol for application of the reductant may simply contribute to gas exchange in the reactor and result in lower O2 concentration. Reductants that are more effective than ethylene help consume residual O2 more rapidly by generating reduced chromium that serves as an O2 trap; however, they may not necessarily produce active sites themselves. Finally, reductants may actually lead to active sites; for example, 1-hexene has been proposed to provide ligands to the active site [6]. It has already been recognized before that metal alkyl activators can serve as scavengers of poisons such as oxygen or water [2]. Usually, the rising activity has been associated with the formation of Cr-alkyls, since Cr(II)/silica also exhibits a rising rate [2]. This may still be correct, only the net formation rate may be dictated by a decreasing reoxidation rate in the reactor. 4.5 Chemistry reversing the effect of O2 poisoning The reversibility of O2 poisoning, seen at the O2 levels applied in this work, poses questions regarding the chemistry. Earlier studies [6,25,36] demonstrated that the initial redox products cannot be desorbed by evacuation, or solvents, or heating, but only by hydrolysis. However, the reversibility of oxygen poisoning suggests that whatever the redox products were, they are nevertheless somehow removed. One would think that these products, even if displaced from the Cr, would still remain in a closed system, where they could inhibit polymerization. However, the maximum final rate for some oxygen-poisoned catalysts recovered to nearly the same full rate as that of unperturbed catalysts. This suggests little or no inhibition by the “liberated” redox products. It was noted in an earlier report [41] that quenching a polymerization reaction with oxygen produced oxygenated polymer chains. This accommodation of O2 could be one explanation for the dilemma. Oxygen-terminated macro-chains would not necessarily inhibit further polymerization, given their size and lack of mobility. This explanation could apply most directly to injection of oxygen during the polymerization, but even injection before polymerization might produce a short chain before the poison can react. Another potential explanation is that the active site can retain some ligands without major loss of activity [6]. This placement of O2 raises the question of how many redox cycles the catalyst can sustain in-situ, re-oxidation followed by re-reduction, each cycle potentially leaving a redox product. Another question is that of O2 poison stoichiometry. The usual expectation is that Cr(VI) would be most easily reduced to Cr(IV), in which case, only one oxygen atom might be needed for oxidation. Reoxidation of Cr(III) might be more complicated, and reoxidation of Cr(II) should be fast, requiring two oxygen atoms. Placing oxygen on the terminated chain or on other resident ligands would add to this oxygen demand. Finally, it is worth pointing out that not all sites are equal. A series of experiments with gradually increasing degree of chromium reduction by CO yielded polymer with decreasing melt index [12], suggesting that a site distribution exists. The sites are distinguished by their reducibility and, correlated to that, by the properties of polymer that they produce. The model presented is based on data from the very early stages of reduction, and therefore, extrapolation to stages with deeper degrees of reduction may face limitations. On the other hand, the model demonstrates that early-stage reduction is well captured by a single rate coefficient. 5 Conclusions The induction time and the period of rising activity that are both typical of the Phillips catalyst can be modeled with the time-dependent O2 concentration as the decisive parameter. The results indicate that any residual O2 trapped in reactors or dead volumes (e.g., pressure gauges), released from reactor surfaces or seals, trapped in the catalyst pores, or adsorbed on its surface, or introduced with a gas stream will prolong the induction period. The surprise is perhaps that the behavior can be explained on the basis of the effect of O2 alone, and no other rate-limiting step has to be invoked. The observation thus does not preclude that the proposed chemistries or site formation reactions occur, but they may not dictate the length of the induction period or the increase in rate thereafter. In the flow setup that was used, the main source of oxygen was external to the reactor, that is, oxygen was introduced with the feed stream, which was contaminated enroute from gas tanks to reactor. The catalyst became active once the influx dropped below a certain level such that reduction by ethylene prevailed. To transfer the model to another reactor configuration, the source of O2 would have to be identified. In addition to the feed stream, any reservoirs such as dead volumes or materials adsorbing O2 inside the reactor (walls, seals) may have to be considered. The model then can be adapted accordingly. Similarly, the model could be adapted for any other poison, and for different temperatures and ethylene concentrations, both of which have a strong effect on the induction time. The findings also have implications for the evaluation of reductants. The following effects must be considered: • additional gas exchange in the reactor while the reductant is applied • generation of reduced sites that serve as O2 traps • generation of reduced and active sites with the reductant’s oxidation products serving as ligand. In conclusion, several important findings concerning the Phillips catalyst were made in this investigation. First, the powerful poisoning effect that oxygen has on the catalyst was illustrated. And yet, it has also been shown that the poisoning can be reversible, meaning that sites rendered inoperative by oxygen can be reactivated. Finally, oxygen contamination has been quantitatively linked with the induction time of the catalyst: The induction time and the period of rising activity are extended until all of the oxygen in the reactor has been consumed. coredata.dc:description: The Phillips catalyst, which accounts for a large fraction of the world’s linear polyethylene, is known for an induction period without appreciable ethylene consumption, followed by a period of rising activity, which together can last an hour or two. In this investigation, the effect of trace amounts of a ubiquitous contaminant, molecular oxygen, on the length of the induction period is determined. Experiments were conducted in a tubular flow reactor with a packed bed of 1 or 3 wt% Cr on SiO2. The protocol was to first treat Cr(VI)/SiO2 at a temperature of 600 °C in 50 % O2, then cool and adjust the residual O2 concentration at the reactor inlet to between about 50 to 500 ppm by an inert gas purge, with optional application of 1-hexene as reductant. Polymerization was conducted at a temperature of 100 °C and ethylene partial pressures of 10 to 18 kPa. The length of the induction period and the time to reach maximum activity correlated with the O2 concentration at the inlet. The observations were qualitatively confirmed by high-pressure (3.79 MPa) experiments with slurried catalyst, which also demonstrated that the effect of O2 can be transient, and the catalyst reaches its full polymerization activity. An adaptable model of competing reduction and reoxidation rates in the packed-bed reactor is presented that accurately predicts the length of the induction time based on O2 level and the amount of catalyst loaded into the reactor. .
